awd_titl_txt: GOALI: Characterization of Material Transfer in Friction Stir Processing With a Consumable Tool
awd_abstract_narration:
This Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) project will address the fundamental issue of material transfer from one metal to another at high force and temperature, called friction surfacing.  This is based on friction stir welding technology in which a rotating tool is forced into a material to simultaneously deform, heat, and mix material.  There is an increasing need for dissimilar material surfacing and coating applications.  The major advantage of this technique is material adheres by mechanical bonding at relatively low temperature, resulting in high bonding strength, high tolerance to contamination, low environmental impact, and at low cost.  The technical challenge centers on the nature of material transfer, adhesion and deposited material properties.  This is collaborative research between the University of Hawaii at Manoa and General Motors.  Two target applications have been identified for this research 1) Automotive - Conventional coating processes have not proven particularly suitable for steel and lightweight materials and have had limited success. What is therefore needed is an efficient and easily-operated technique to modify the surface composition of metal parts to make them more corrosion resistant. 2) Naval - the seals in ships are susceptible to corrosion and the current electroplating protection method is not adequate for coating nickel alloys onto the corroded, unclean steel hull. These industries are central to American national security and economic welfare. This research will also impact remanufacturing applications as an alternative method of coating/cladding by mechanical transfer of material.  The PIs will work with native Hawaiian students on this research through the Native Hawaiian Science & Engineering Mentorship Program at the University of Hawaii at Manoa.

The goal of this project is to characterize material transfer in friction surfacing with a consumable tool.  The research will generate knowledge about parameters and conditions for transfer of material from one surface to another, which is important for all friction stir processes. The properties of tool and substrate for which material is being transferred will be characterized. The nature of adhesion between transferred material and substrate will be studied through a series of fundamental experimental measurements, metallurgy, and modeling to establish the relationship among the process parameters, process conditions, material transfer, and adhesion to the work material. The plan is to 1) experimentally measure the effects of process parameters and conditions on amount and quality of transferred material from the consumable tool to the rigid surface 2) establish metallurgy of the transferred material and adhesion 3) model the process for knowledge about distribution of stress, strain, and temperature throughout the material and 4) quantify the comparative performance and properties of the new coatings. This is a new direction for friction stir processing.  General Motors is contributing much expertise and guidance to this project, which will enhance its technical relevance.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
In this research, a novel solid-state deposition approach called lateral friction surfacing was studied. In this technique, the radial surface of a rotating consumable tool is forced into the substrate surface, facilitating material transfer from the tool to the substrate. In the friction stir processing field, it is well known that metallic material can be softened and deformed in a semi-solid state through high force and frictional heating. This research takes this concept a step further by leveraging the force and temperature to deposit one material onto another. The mechanism of deposition of the consumable tool material onto the rigid substrate is through thermal softening and plastic deformation enabled by high force and frictional heating. The process was carried out at temperatures below the melting point of the consumable material, resulting in a solid-state deposition process. In conventional friction surfacing, material is transferred from the end of the rotating tool. The principal difference in this study is that the material transfer occurs from the radial surface of the tool. 

The process parameters and conditions for successful transfer of material were found through experimental and finite element methods. Deposition thickness and quality were found to be dependent on several important process parameters such as pressing force, table traverse speed, spindle speed, tool/substrate materials, and the number of deposition passes. The experimental results revealed that the normal force and tool rotational speed are the critical controlling parameters to adjust the input energy into the process. Therefore, increasing the input energy by adopting higher forces, higher rotational speeds, and rougher surfaces may lead to deposition of materials with higher melting points. Distribution of temperature, stress, and strain were mapped in the tool and substrate during the process in finite element simulation. Metallurgical analysis was done to show cross-sectional images of the structure and composition of the deposited coatings. Complete mechanical bonding, subsurface defects, and different elements introduced by mixing and diffusion were found in the cross sectional views. 

The direct outcome is a novel, alternative method of coating/cladding and possibly crack filling by mechanical transfer of material that is much different than the current methods. This has impact in coating, galvanization, and remanufacturing applications. The lateral friction surfacing technique is an excellent alternative to create ultra-thin and ultra-smooth metallic deposit layers for repairing damaged surfaces or improving corrosion and wear resistance. The surface roughness of the coating layers were measured to be less than 1 micron. Deposition by lateral friction surfacing is possible at a significantly lower temperature compared to that by conventional friction surfacing, which reduces thermal impacts on grain structure and metallurgical properties. The results of the experimental study demonstrated that lateral friction surfacing is capable of fabricating aluminum alloys with great coverage; however, the limitations in the values of process parameters should be considered like any other manufacturing processes. 

Two PhD students were supported in the project. A supplement to this project was internship support where both PhD students participated in non-academic internships at General Motors Corporation, the industrial collaborator on this project. This led to collaboration on a different research topic that enhanced the education of the students and made advances in metal plasticity that is relevant in stamping and forming processing.

Modified by: Scott F Miller
